text:
Assessing the internal character,
reservoir potential, and seal
competence of mass-transport
deposits using seismic texture:
A geophysical and
petrophysical approach

Tiago M. Alves, Kuncho Kurtev,
Gregory F. Moore, and Michael Strasser
ABSTRACT

Three-dimensional (3-D) seismic volumes from southeast
Brazil, southeast Japan, and borehole data from the Ocean
Drilling and Integrated Ocean Drilling Programs are used to
demonstrate a new method to distinguish mass-transport de-
posits (MTDs) from confining hemipelagites, quantify MTDs
internal architecture, and assess their reservoir potential or seal
competence—the contrast, directionality, energy (CDE) meth-
od. The CDE values extracted from 3-D seismic data can be tied
to any ground-truthed property of strata regardless of their
depositional history, age, and lithology. The application of the
CDE method is, however, dependent on seismic-data acqui-
sition parameters and selected processing sequences and should
be independently applied to different seismic volumes. Bore-
hole data indicate contrast (C) to reflect MTDs lithological
heterogeneity and degree of disaggregation, which increase
proportionally to the absolute value of C. More uniform values
of P-wave velocity (Vp) and peak shear strength are recorded in
strata with lower contrast. Directionality (D) relates to the
existence of syn- or postdepositional fabric such as compres-
sional ridges, imbricated strata or faults. Energy (E) relates to
the acoustic impedance of strata, with high-amplitude reflec-
tions correlating with strata with higher shear strength, i.e.,
high Vp and shear-wave velocity (Vs) values, or with abrupt

Michael Strasser conducts research on the
quantitative characterization of dynamic sedi-

contrasts in density (bright spots). This work shows that dis-
tinct values of C, D, and E reflect variable degrees of vertical
and horizontal connectivity in strata and, consequently, their
seal and reservoir potential. The CDE values are thus sub-
divided in nine classes, which are represented in ternary plots
to cover the full spectrum of MTDs and any confining strata.
As a result, the data in this article confirm that lower seal
competence, and higher reservoir potential, is recorded in
strata with large D or moderate CDE values.

INTRODUCTION

Landslide deposits reflect gravitational movements of near-
surface strata in which the internal cohesion of failed material
is maintained (Nemec, 1990; Hampton et al., 1996; Locat,
2001; Everhøi et al., 2005; Lee et al., 2006; Sultan et al., 2007).
Onshore landslide deposits are commonly remobilized through
relatively small distances (Varnes, 1978; Mulder and Cochonat,
1996; Burg et al., 2008). In contrast, submarine landslides can
reach hundreds of kilometers in single or recurrent instability
events, which commonly result in the accumulation of large vol-
umes of strata, or mass-transport deposits (MTDs) (Hühnerbach
et al., 2004; Moscardelli and Wood, 2008). Similar instability
phenomena are observed on other planets, where it is believed
that earthquakes, or hydrologic cycles, are of enough magni-
tude to trigger large-scale slope instability on weakened surface
rocks (McEwen, 1989; Schulz, 2002; Lucas and Mangeney,
2007; Moscardelli and Wood, 2011; Moscardelli et al., 2012).
Wireline and sediment core data from continental margins
around the world have shown that distinct degrees of stratal
disaggregation in MTDs are reflected as variations in their struc-
tural and petrophysical properties (Dott, 1963; Nardin et al.,
1979). These variations commonly result in the migration and
escape of fluids to the surface (Paull et al., 1996, 2003; Bünz
et al., 2005; Flemings et al., 2005; Masson et al., 2006), partic-
ularly in regions with low net-to-gross ratios or showing signifi-
cant internal deformation in the form of folds, faults, and frac-
tures (Flemings et al, 2005; Bull et al., 2008). In addition, MTDs
above certain porosity thresholds comprise important hydro-
carbon reservoirs, as in the case of the Oligocene Frio Forma-
tion of south Texas (Ogiesoba and Hammes 2012), the Mio-
cene Harang embankment in Louisiana (Edwards, 2000), or
the prolific Ubit, Asabo, and Enang fields from offshore Nigeria
(Clayton et al., 1998; Apotria et al., 2004; Bruso et al., 2004).
Most of these oil and gas fields comprise either large-scale
blocks or coarse-grained material that was slumped, translated,

and eroded on continental slopes that were later
covered by deep-water shales (Vazquez et al.,
1997; Joiner et al., 1999; Galloway et al., 2000;
Abreu and Hill, 2004; Moscardelli and Wood,
2008). In such complex stratigraphic successions,
to recognize and describe MTDs was shown to be
crucial to optimal well planning and hydrocarbon
production (Ogiesoba and Hammes, 2012).
Notwithstanding their economic importance,
a key difficulty when interpreting buried MTDs
concerns their recognition as either reservoir in-
tervals or competent seal units. Caveats are par-
ticularly recorded when interpreting older MTDs,
knowing of their tendency to lose diagnostic fea-
tures with increasing compaction. In fact, original
depositional features, compartmentalization styles,
dips of remnant strata, and degree of strata disrup-
tion (or tortuosity, sensu Salem and Chilingarian,
2000; Matthews et al., 2008; Tiab and Donaldson,
2011) approach those of confining bedded strata at
depths of 7000–10,000 ft (2133–3048 m) (Ogiesoba
and Hammes, 2012). Advanced methods to recog-
nize MTDs, and their internal character, are there-
fore necessary to assist their interpretation in deeply
buried successions. In particular, any new methods
must be useful (1) to assess seal competence in
stratigraphic sequences recording multiple insta-
bility events, (2) to understand the reservoir po-
tential of individual MTDs, and (3) to examine the
degree of recurrence and regional scales of individ-
ual mass-transport events (Day et al., 1999; Driscoll
et al., 2000; Masson et al., 2002; Haflidason et al.,
2004; Pérez-Torrado et al., 2006; Urgeles et al., 2007;
Lee, 2009; Yamada et al., 2012). New methods
should also be applicable to different geophysical
data sets, ranging from industry three-dimensional
(3-D) seismic volumes to high-resolution reflec-
tion profiles. They should also be applicable to data
sets such as side-scan sonar mosaics, bathymetric
maps, chirp profiles, or light detection and ranging
(LIDAR), in both the two-dimensional (R2) and
three-dimensional space (R3) (Metternicht et al.,
2005).
In this article, we use high-quality 3-D seismic
volumes from southeast Japan and southeast Bra-
zil, together with borehole data from the Nankai
Trough and 11 other drilling sites from the Ocean

Drilling Program (ODP) and Integrated Ocean
Drilling Program (IODP) to demonstrate a new
method to recognize MTDs, assess their seal com-
petence, and conclude on their reservoir potential
(Figure 1). The new method is based on three tex-
tural parameters on seismic data: contrast (C), di-
rectionality (D), and energy (E). Seismic texture is
defined as a reflection amplitude pattern charac-
terized by the magnitude and variation of neigh-
boring data in a seismic volume (Haralick et al.,
1973; Gao, 2003; Chopra and Marfurt, 2007). The
three parameters proposed here are subdivided
into nine different classes, and their distribution is
plotted on ternary diagrams to represent the in-
ternal fabric and seismic texture of MTDs. The re-
sulting contrast, directionality and energy (CDE)
distribution plots can be tied to ground-truthed
properties of MTDs derived from downhole, wire-
line, or sediment core data. The CDE method is
therefore applicable to individual geophysical data
sets allowing attribute extraction from MTDs. In
summary, the scientific objectives of this article are
as follows:

• To present a new methodology to characterize
MTDs in terms of their internal architecture;
• To investigate how the parameters used in the
new methodology, contrast (C), directionality
(D), and energy (E), relate to lithological and
petrophysical variations in MTDs;
• To propose ternary diagrams as the best way to
distinguish MTDs in terms of their CDE values
and, thus, assess their reservoir potential and seal
competence.

The article starts by summarizing the internal
character of MTDs on seismic and borehole data,
based on Deep-Sea Drilling Program (DSDP), ODP,
and IODP data. It then continues by presenting the
mathematical and geophysical concepts behind the
new CDE method. In the data analysis section, we
test the CDE method in three case studies from
southeast Japan (Nankai Trough) and southeast
Brazil (Espírito Santo Basin) (Figure 1). Borehole
data from the IODP Expedition 333 are used to
correlate the petrophysical properties of drilled
strata with their CDE distribution. At the end of the

specific regions of MTDs, and (2) seal compe-
tence and reservoir potential as a function of CDE
distribution.
DATA AND METHODS
This work used 3-D seismic data covering 672 km2

(259 mi2) of the continental slope offshore Nankai
(southeast Japan) and 2400 km2 (927 mi2) of the
Espírito Santo Basin (southeast Brazil) (Figures 1,
2). The interpreted seismic volumes were chosen
for comprising high-resolution data in two regions
where stratigraphic control exists on the inter-
preted successions. The southeast Japan prestack
depth migrated (PSDM) volume is located in a
region drilled by multiple IODP expeditions (Ex-
pedition 314 Scientists, 2009; Expedition 316 Sci-
entists, 2009a, b; Expedition 333 Scientists, 2011;
Moore et al., 2013) (Figures 2A, 3A, 4A). Offshore
Nankai, drilled strata comprise clays and silts al-
ternating with coarser turbidites and volcaniclastic
intervals (Figure 5A). Vertical seismic resolution
approaches 6 m (20 ft) in the PSDM volume of
southeast Japan based on the dominant wave-
length of approximately 24 m (79 ft) observed on
synthetic logs and seismic profiles (Figure 5A).
This same seismic volume has an inline spacing of
12.5 m (41.0 ft), a crossline spacing of 18.75 m
(61.52 ft), with a sampling interval of 5 ms. Its
processing sequence included prestack multiple
removal and data conditioning (amplitude recov-
ery, time-variant filtering, and predictive decon-
volution), followed by 3-D prestack depth migra-
tion (Moore et al., 2007).
In the case study from southeast Brazil, the fo-
cus was on two distinct 3-D seismic volumes ac-
quired south the Abrolhos Bank, a large volca-
nic plateau that sourced volcaniclastic sands and
shales to the continental slope from the Eocene
to the present day (Fiduk et al., 2004; Schreiner
et al., 2009) (Figure 2B, C). Interpreted Miocene–
Holocene strata thus comprise interbedded car-
bonate and siliciclastic units, megablocks, sand, and
gravels sourced from the Abrolhos Bank (Fiduk

C). Seismic resolution for the intervals of interest in
this article approaches 10 m (33 ft) in the two in-

from the BES-100 and BM-ES-1 (Figure 1C). This

streamers. Data processing included resampling,

one-pass 3-D migration.
In this work, MTDs are imaged using root-mean-
square (RMS) amplitude, coherence, and dip maps.

surements of the RMS amplitude of a seismic
wave reflected at normal incidence on an inter-
face (Brown, 2011). The peak amplitudes of re-
flected seismic waves, positive or negative, are
root-squared into positive values of amplitude,
thus emphasizing large reflection events over low-
amplitude background strata. Coherence maps
provide measurements of the continuity between

seismic traces in a specified window (Brown, 2011).
Coherence attributes are particularly helpful to
recognize faults, blocks, and other features that
disrupt the lateral continuity of seismic reflections.
Dip maps compute best-fit planes between im-
mediate neighbour traces on a time or depth slice
and calculate magnitude (gradient) of dip (Brown,
2011). Dip values are measured in degrees in re-
lation to a horizontal plane.
GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL BACKGROUND
Geological Setting of Southeast Japan

The Nankai Trough results from the subduction of
the Philippine Sea plate beneath the Eurasian plate
along southeast Japan (Figure 1B). The study area
is located in the imbricate thrust zone (ITZ) of the
Nankai Trough, a highly deformed area of the con-
tinental slope of southeast Japan (Moore et al.,
2009) (Figures 1B, 2A). Here, the continental slope
is dominated by a megasplay fault (MSF) separating
the ITZ from an inner forearc basin to the north-
west of the study area (Kumano Basin, Park et al.,
2002; Tobin and Kinoshita, 2006) (Figures 1B, 3A,
4A). Seaward from the MSF, a submarine channel
system and recurrent MTDs (MTDs 1 to 6; Expe-
dition 333 Scientists, 2011) were generated in what
was interpreted as a broad zone of deformation
(Alves, 2013) (Figures 3A, 4A).
The present-day tectonic and depositional set-
tings of the ITZ were initiated at approximately
2.2 Ma in a frontal wedge-toe position (Strasser
et al., 2011). Splay-fault movement was initiated
at about 1.95 Ma in the lower part of the wedge.
Ongoing megasplay slip occurs since about 1.55 Ma
(Strasser et al., 2009). As a result of the complex

ward from the MSF rangefrom 2.87 Ma to Holocene
(<100 yr b.p.) (Kimura et al., 2011; Strasser et al.,

Seismic stratigraphic units in the Nankai Trough
are shown in Figure 5A and correlated with bore-
hole data from IODP Hole C0018A (Expedition
333 Scientists, 2011). In the ITZ, the largest MTD
6 has a maximum thickness of 182 m (597 ft) and
an area approaching 20 km2 (7.7 mi2) (Strasser
et al., 2011). The MTD 6 divides the slope sedi-
ments into two distinct subunits; unit Ib, com-
prising a sandy turbidite sequence, and unit Ia
with ash-bearing hemipelagites and multiple MTDs
(Figures 4A, 5A). The larger MTD 6 has been drilled
and cored at Site C0018A, where it reaches a thick-
ness of 61.5 m (201.7 ft), and was emplaced be-
tween 0.85 and 1.05 Ma (Expedition 333 Scien-
tists, 2011; Strasser et al., 2012). Above this,
MTD 5 comprises a younger instability episode
and is part of unit Ia (Expedition 316 Scientists,
2009a, b) (Figures 4A, 5A).
Geological Setting Offshore Southeast Brazil

The Espírito Santo Basin is the northernmost of
a series of Upper Jurassic–Cretaceous rift basins
developed in southeast Brazil (Chang et al., 1992)
(Figure 1C). Following synrift extension, the early
postrift geology of the basin was dominated by
the accumulation of large volumes of Aptian evap-
orites, an event followed by the incision of sub-
marine channel systems and the triggering of signif-
icant mass-wasting events in the Cenozoic (Moreira
and Carminatti, 2004). From the Late Cretaceous
onward, at least eight episodes of channel incision
are recorded on the continental slope of Espírito

highly deformed sediments with no original depo-
sitional structures or, instead, a mix of moderate
deformed to undeformed intervals with a great part
of the original bedding still preserved in the form
of remnant and rafted strata (Bull et al., 2008;
Alves, 2010; Alves and Lourenço, 2010; Gamboa
et al., 2011).
Bull et al. (2008) demonstrated that mass
movements generate specific kinematic indicators,
depending on the relative location of strata in rela-
tion to the headwall (proximal erosive), transla-
tional (intermediate), and toe (distal) parts of
MTDs. This is an important character, as strata
within specific zones of MTDs can show similar
deformation styles, basal erosional features, and
boundary features regardless of their size or litho-
logical nature (Varnes, 1978; Frey-Martinez et al.,
2006; Bull et al., 2008). However, the provenance
(i.e., source strata) and magnitude of downslope
transport of MTDs are key factors controlling
their internal architecture (e.g., Jenner et al., 2007;
Omosanya and Alves, 2013), commonly adding
complexity to any MTD classification based on 3-D
geomorphological features alone. Provenance and
transporting distances are also important controls
on MTD potential as seals or reservoirs because
porosity and permeability are significantly reduced
after downslope gravitational movements be-
cause of the high degree of deformation they show
(Moscardelli et al., 2006). In contrast, MTDs
showing small transporting distances show vari-
able lithologies, and variable porosity and per-
meability of strata in their interior, characters that
increase their reservoir potential (Ogiesoba and
Hammes, 2012).
Borehole data from offshore Nankai (Strasser
et al., 2012), Gulf of Mexico (Flemings et al., 2005),
and 10 other DSDP, ODP, and IODP drilling sites
showed MTDs to comprise heterogeneous depos-
its with distinct degrees of internal deformation,
their lithologies ranging from brecciated to fine
clay material deposited in distinct depositional
and tectonic settings (e.g., Amazon Fan, Flood
et al., 1997; Gulf of Mexico, Flemings et al., 2005;
Nankai Trough, Mikada et al., 2005; Walvis Ridge,
Kroonet al.,2007; Dugan,2012;Strasser et al.,2012)
(Figures 5A, 6). As a result of their heterogeneity,

Santo (Fiduk et al., 2004). Sediment progradation
onto the continental slope also resulted in signifi-
cant halokinesis, further destabilizing the south-
east Brazilian margin and feeding large salt fair-
ways, canopies, and diapirs toward the distal slope
(e.g., Fiduk et al., 2004). These phenomena oc-
curred together with thin-skinned extension up-
slope because of the gravitational gliding of post-
salt strata (Demercian et al., 1993), in large-scale
movements that were also facilitated by volcanic
activity at the Abrolhos Bank between 60 and
40 Ma (Mohriak, 2005).
The seismic stratigraphy of the Espírito Santo
Basin is shown in Figure 5B. The MTDs analyzed
in this article are part of the N20–N60 sequences,
which comprise an alternating succession of chaotic
to continuous reflections, at places interrupted by
incising submarine channels (Figures 3B, C; 4A, B).
Moreira and Carminatti (2004) interpreted the
N20–N60 sequences as representing successive re-
gressive and transgressive events on the Brazilian
margin. The age of N20–N60 ranges from the early
Miocene to Holocene, meaning that it is age equiva-
lent to the Rio Doce (siliciclastic), Caravelas (carbon-
ate), and Urucutuca (shaley) Members (Figure 5B).
In the BES-100 volume, the N20–N60 sequences
comprise an alternation of the three latter units
(França et al., 2007) (Figures 3B, 4B). In the BE-
MS-1 volume, the interpreted MTDs are part of a
moderate- to low-amplitude sequence, at places de-
formed by closely spaced normal faults (Figures 3C,
4C). These strata should correspond to an alter-
nation of shales and sands deposited in the lower
slope region of Espírito Santo.

SEISMIC AND PETROPHYSICAL CHARACTER
OF MASS-TRANSPORT DEPOSITS

On seismic-reflection data, MTDs are commonly
shown as intervals of distinct seismic amplitudes
and facies when compared with confining units
above and below (Ogiesoba and Hammes, 2012).
They commonly present chaotic to deformed in-
ternal reflections with evidence of downslope grav-
itational transport (Nardin et al., 1979; Moscardelli
and Wood, 2008). Therefore, MTDs can comprise

(B) Velocity (Vp) and density values for mass-

seismic-borehole correlations commonly show
MTDs to comprise intervals with significant var-
iations in P-wave velocity (Vp) and peak shear
strength when compared with adjacent strata
(Figure 5A; MTDs 2 and 4 in Figure 6A, B).
Ayres and Theilen (2001) demonstrated in the
Barents Sea that variations in Vp and shear-wave
velocity (Vs) relate to changes in the compress-
ibility of sea-floor sediments. These changes are, in
turn, associated with variations in lithology, po-
rosity, degree of cementation, and amounts of sand
and silt in strata (Flodin et al., 2003, 2005). In
detail, Vs is particularly sensitive to changes in the
compressibility of shales, an observation that led

between geophysical and petrophysical data must

tural features can be used to characterize an image
volume. In the specific case of MTDs, their internal
variability can be specifically quantified by three
distinct textural parameters: contrast, directional-
ity, and energy. Contrast (C) indicates the relative
degree of heterogeneity and disaggregation of strata,
parameters that are useful to discriminate remnant
strata from slumps, slides, or debris flows (Nardin
et al., 1979). Directionality (D) is related to the
presence of kinematic indicators, faults, remnant or
rafted blocks, and complex internal fabrics (e.g., Bull
et al., 2008). It also relates to any inherited (or
postdepositional) fabric that may affect perme-
ability in 3-D. Energy (E) gives an account of strata
reflectivity, itself a function of their acoustic im-
pedance. On image data, these three textural pa-
rameters can be defined by the following equations
(see Chopra and Marfurt, 2007). In equations 2 to
4, Pi,j denotes the ith row and the jth column of a
co-occurrence matrix:

1. Contrast is a measure of the contrast of the image
or of the amount of local variation present in an
image:

in which Kb and N are the frame moduli, and Kp
describes the pore space effects of fluid saturation,
Sw, and porosity, f (Murphy et al., 1991). Equation 1
indicates that harder sediment with higher values
of shear strength, if not filled by a fluid of lower
density, has higher Vp values, particularly when
dealing with sharp rheological contrasts between,
for instance, sands and clays (e.g., Koesoemadinata
and McMechan, 2001; Blanchard et al., 2010).
This postulate confirms the overall trend for higher
peak values in Vp and density recorded in most
MTDs drilled at DSDP, ODP, and IODP sites,
which essentially crossed heterogeneous MTDs
comprising a mixture of sand, silt, clay, and lithified
sediments (Figures 1A, 5A, 6).

Contrast is high for strata with contrasting am-
plitudes. Conversely, the directionality of strata
is low when contrast is high. Contrast (C) relates
to the degree of disaggregation of MTDs with
the larger values indicating highly disaggregated,
heterolithic deposits.

and Marfurt, 2007) is a measure of the overall
smoothness of an image:

Energy (E) can be correlated with the presence
of high-amplitude strata, e.g., cemented sands or
clays, hydrocarbon accumulations, carbonates,
and intervals significantly affected by diagenesis.
Conversely, E is low when all the elements in the
matrix are equal and of low amplitude.

The Chopra and Marfurt (2007) method is
applied by compiling co-occurrence and proba-
bility tables for any relevant seismic attribute (i.e.,
amplitude, coherence, magnitude, etc.) for spe-
cific directions. For instance, in MTDs with a
marked internal fabric high-amplitude features
can be preferentially aligned, thus implying that
permeability can be lower in different directions
to this latter fabric. The interpreter should thus
consider the co-occurrence matrix that is the most
conservative for a specific direction q (0°, 45°, 90°,
or 135°).
Co-occurrence matrices are, however, of dif-
ficult application when using common seismic
interpretation techniques. In the published lit-
erature, basic attribute maps such as RMS am-
plitude, reflection strength, variance or coherence,
dip, structural, and thickness maps are exten-
sively used to characterize MTDs (Bull et al.,
2008; Moscardelli and Wood, 2008; Alves, 2010).
Any new methods should, therefore, abridge
the Chopra and Marfurt (2007) method with
seismic attribute maps used by academia and
industry.

THE CONTRAST, DIRECTIONALITY, ENERGY
METHOD: ABRIDGING TWO-DIMENSIONAL
AND THREE-DIMENSIONAL
TEXTURAL PARAMETERS

Matrices are proposed as the best tools to rep-
resent the complex variability of MTDs in 3-D,
abridging seismic texture analyses and seismic

attribute maps computed during seismic interpre-
tation. Matrices relate to linear maps by mathe-
matically representing an orientation vector within
an area (R2) or in a volume (R3) (Datta, 2010).
Finally, they facilitate operations such as multi-
plications and additions between measured phys-
ical and acoustic properties. By using matrices to
define the internal character of MTDs, the inter-
preter can also introduce a pondering factor, c, to
any confirmed physical property, as matrices rep-
resent linear transformations of the form f(x) = cx,
with c being a constant (Datta, 2010). Hence, in
the 3-D space, the seismic texture of MTDs can be
represented by a 3 × 3 square matrix of the type

Two caveats when applying the CDE method
comprise (1) the use of different amplitude spec-
trums in CDE calculations caused by the merging
of different seismic volumes, and (2) the use of
volumes with distinct decimations and sampling
intervals. The extraction of CDE values is only
meaningful if the vertical resolution of the seismic
signal is enough to resolve any offsets and geolog-
ical features within MTDs, i.e., observed changes
in stratal or fault dips depend on the bin size of the
seismic volume as well as its vertical and lateral
resolution (Yilmaz, 1987). In this case, coarse data
decimations and vertical samplings will obliterate
part of the amplitude signal of seismic data, re-
ducing the accuracy of the interpretation.
Another limitation arises from the fact that
absolute values of amplitude recorded by a seis-
mic volume depend primarily on the energy and
type of signal source(s) used during acquisition, as
well as on any bypass frequency filtering and am-
plitude boost selected during processing (Damuth,
1980; Damuth et al., 1988; Evans, 1997). Aggres-
sive frequency bypass filters applied during data
processing result in the significant trimming of

The interpreter must calculate, for each pa-

if extracted seismic-attribute magnitudes are rela-
tively large, average, or low. For instance, a C1-D3-
E2 interval represents one with low contrast, highly
directional, moderate-energy strata. In practice,
the interpreter can extract the absolute values for

seismic amplitudes, with the resulting loss of sig-
nificant information (Yilmaz, 1987). In addition to
data trimming, the amplitude spectrum of seismic
data, maximum penetration depths, and vertical
and horizontal resolutions depend on the seismic
source used, i.e., if the acquisition system is of
moderate, high, or low resolution (see Faugères
et al., 1999, for an impact of different seismic
methods in the visualization of deep-marine strata).
In practice, this signifies that too low a signal fre-
quency or spatial Nyquist number (a function of
the CMP trace spacing and acquisition geome-
try) will have an impact on what features are
resolved on distinct 3-D volumes. Low vertical
and horizontal resolutions can cause thin MTDs
to be shown as fairly continuous strata or be
completely unresolved (Widess, 1973; Morlet
et al., 1982).
Despite these limitations, directionality (D)
should remain relatively constant in distinct 3-D
volumes if linear features are resolved, as it com-
prises a seismic textural feature independent from
selected acquisition parameters. For the purpose of
recognizing MTDs from confining hemipelagites,
depth-converted data should be primarily used to
calculate D, but the interpreter can also use two-
way time volumes to calculate a relative (two-
way time) D value, also considering that dips are
progressively hard to resolve with depth. Time-
depth conversions can also be applied locally to
PSTM volumes to better estimate the absolute val-
ues of D.
Absolute amplitude values used in the calcu-
lation of E and C can, however, vary significantly
depending on signal strength, frequency, and acous-
tic source(s) used. To limit any discrepancies, am-
plitude values of MTDs should be considered in
the CDE method relative to the background
amplitude of confining strata. In this article, we
homogenized C and E values using an algorithm
that considers the full spectrum of amplitudes
within hemipelagites and continuous strata con-
fining the MTDs to which the CDE method is
applied. This same algorithm converts absolute
values of C, D, and E in a constant sum, a necessary
condition to represent CDE values in ternary plots
(Figure 8).

MAPPING THE INTERNAL VARIABILITY
OF MASS-TRANSPORT DEPOSITS
ON SEISMIC DATA

Considering seismic attribute maps are compiled
within a window small enough that the low-pass
filtering effects from masking remain tolerable, yet
large enough that the extracted information ex-
hibits statistical significance (Brown, 2011), MTDs
should be first recognized using the common in-
terpretation criteria; they comprise chaotic to struc-
turally deformed strata showing evidence of down-
slope movement or kinematic indicators on seismic
data (Bull et al., 2008) (Figure 9). These kinematic
indicators can include features as varied as scours
(Posamentier and Kolla, 2003; Weimer and Shipp,
2004), basal grooves and striations (Gee et al.,
2006), cat claws (Moscardelli et al., 2006), monkey
fingers (McGilvery and Cook, 2003), frontal and
lateral ramps and flats (Lucente and Pini, 2003),
and faults and compressional ridges (Frey-Martinez
et al., 2006).
To apply the CDE method, the top and basal
surfaces of MTDs should be mapped in detail. These
top and basal surfaces will limit the seismic vol-
ume in which CDE values will be extracted. The
second interpretation step consists in the com-
pilation of attribute maps (or 3-D volumes) from
available geophysical data (Figure 9). When using
3-D seismic data, we favor the compilation of plan-
view attribute data in the form of RMS ampli-
tude and maximum magnitude (e.g., reflection
strength, cf., Brown, 2011) maps in successive in-
tervals crossing the MTDs to account for their 3-D
variability (see Zeng et al., 1998a, b). Root-mean-
square amplitude or maximum-magnitude maps
provide phase-independent records of amplitude
variations and highlight high-amplitude strata, in-
dependently of their polarity, from low-amplitude
features (Brown, 2011). Reflective features such as
remnant strata, or variations in the physical prop-
erties of MTDs that lead to contrasts in acoustic
impedance, are shown as subgeometric features of
relatively high reflection strength (i.e., Energy), if
spatially resolved on seismic data. Relatively intact
blocks of strata can also be shown as zones with
higher numbers of zero crossings, or low acoustic

variance, in contrast to debrites. Hence, when ap-
plying the CDE method, the interpreter should
also be aware of vertical-section geometry and sizes
of resolvable features in the interpreted strata, as
well as the polarity of reflections inside and on the
flanks of MTDs.
The third step in the CDE method is to verify
the vertical resolution of resolved geological fea-
tures within MTDs, as well as the degree of
structural complexity experienced by failed strata
(Figure 9). Values of C and E can be calculated in a
fourth step by extracting amplitude values from
predefined (cropped) volumes in MTDs, between
their top and bottom surfaces, before being plotted
with directionality (D) on ternary plots (Figure 8).
Steps 5 and 6 comprise the extraction of strata
dips from these same volumetric attributes, and
the final C, D, and E values plotted following the
workflow in Figure 9. Chaos, coherence, and dip
values can also be extracted to assist the inter-
pretation of the MTD acoustic variability.

TESTING THE CONTRAST, DIRECTIONALITY,
ENERGY METHOD
MTDs 5 and 6: Nankai Trough (Southeast Japan)

In the Nankai Trough, IODP Expedition 333 drilled
at Site C0018A a series of Quaternary MTD (MTDs
1 to 6, Strasser et al., 2012; Figure 5A). Strata in
MTD 5 and MTD 6 comprise homogeneous silty
clay, minor amounts of volcaniclastic material, to-
gether with convoluted strata and debrites. In con-
trast, strata below MTD 6 are shown on 3-D seismic
profiles as high-amplitude continuous reflections
(unit Ib, Figures 5A, 10). These continuous strata
in unit Ib comprise well-stratified sandy turbidites,
some volcaniclastic, interbedded with shales and
silts (Figure 5A).

An important feature of both MTD 5 and
MTD 6 is that peak-strength values and bulk den-
sity vary substantially (Figure 5A). This character
suggests seismic waves to be reflected out of rela-
tively undisturbed, lithified strata in the two MTDs,
most likely because of the presence of structurally
deformed intervals and lithified debris-flow clasts in
their interior (see Strasser et al., 2012) (Figure 11B,
C). As a result of these heterogeneities, CDE val-
ues for MTD 5 plot as a scattered distribution of
points, with energy values reaching a maximum
value of approximately 0.5. This distribution results
from the presence of relatively high-amplitude re-
flections in MTD 5 (Figure 11A, E). Some of these
high-amplitude reflections are possibly related to
the presence of free gas and gas hydrates in the
sediment (Kinoshita et al., 2011). In comparison,
MTD 6 plots as strata with relatively high contrast
and relatively lower energy maxima. Directionality
(D) values range here from approximately 5° to

about 45°, a similar value to MTD 5 (Figure 11F).
Strata below MTD 6, comprising laterally contin-
uous turbidite sands with reservoir potential, plot
as a set of CDE points with relatively higher energy
and moderate contrast when compared to MTD 5
and MTD 6 (Figure 11D, G). Here, the scattering
of directionality (D) values is because of strata de-
formation caused by folding and faulting, a con-
trasting feature from remnant strata in the following
case study.

Heterogeneous, Blocky Mass-Transport
Deposits (BES-100, Southeast Brazil)

Root-mean-square amplitude data computed with-
in an interval 40–50 ms above the base of an MTD
from southeast Brazil (Block BES-100, Espírito
Santo Basin) show remnant and rafted blocks in
between chaotic to transparent debrites (Figures 2B,
12). Remnant and rafted blocks are shown as partly
geometric features of high reflection strength
(Figures 13A, 14A). Remnant blocks are com-
monly intersected by faults propagating from un-
derlying strata and do not show any significant

Faulted, Heterogeneous Mass-Transport
Deposits (BM-ES-1, Southeast Brazil)

In this example, two MTDs generated on the flanks
of a rising diapir in Block BM-ES-1, Espírito Santo
Basin, were mapped and analyzed (Figures 2C;
13B, 14B). The uppermost MTD A does not show
remnant and rafted blocks but, instead, is crosscut
by a pervasive fabric, comprising extensional faults
and compressional ridges generated during the ris-
ing of salt diapir B (Figures 13B, 14B). Faults are
shown as low-amplitude lineaments on RMS am-
plitude maps, with high-amplitude strata separat-
ing individual faults, i.e., reflecting an important
contrast between faulted and nonfaulted strata
(Figures 13B, 14B). High-amplitude strata are
likely to comprise interbedded sands and shales
(Fiduk et al., 2004) (Figures 5B). The closely spaced
faults, and moderately deformed strata separating
them, denote limited movement of this MTD,
which was confined to the south and west by ris-
ing salt diapirs (Figures 2C, 13B, 14B). The low-
ermost MTD B comprises chaotic strata deformed
and tilted on the flanks of the rising salt diapir B
(Figures 13B, 14B).
We once again extracted data from seismic
volumes 100 × 100 lines and 100 ms crossing the
faulted, central region of the MTDs (Figure 16A,
B). Amplitude and dip values were extracted from
the volume, and CDE values were plotted in the
ternary diagrams in Figure 16C and D. Strata in the
faulted MTD A plots toward the left of the ternary
diagram (as with MTDs 5 and 6 in Nankai and
area 1 in southeast Brazil), i.e., being predomi-
nantly of the C3 to C2 types. Importantly, the
range in D is relatively wide in the faulted MTD
A for relatively low E values, despite the sharp
contrast in amplitude observed on RMS amplitude
maps (Figure 16B). This latter character results in
high-C strata in MTD A (Figure 16A).
Steeply dipping strata in MTD B are of mod-
erate to low amplitude and have been deformed by
halokinesis and growth of the diapir (Figures 13B,
14B, 16A). As expected, CDE values for MTD B
plot well into the D2 section of the ternary plot,
with low E and moderate C (Figure 16D). This
correlates with the likely presence of low net-to-

gross strata of low E, significantly deformed and
tilted by the rising of salt diapir B.
DISCUSSION

The Contrast, Directionality, Energy Method
and Recognition of Mass-Transport Deposits
on Seismic Data

To demonstrate the use of the CDE method, we
plotted in the ternary diagram in Figure 17 all data
points from the heterogeneous, blocky MTD from
southeast Brazil together with CDE values for
steeply steeping strata flanking diapir B (Figures 13B,
14B, 16A). In this CDE plot, we discriminate be-
tween strata with distinct degrees of disaggregation
alternating and intact blocks with remnant sub-
horizontal strata. Based on the plot in Figure 17 and
on data from the two other case studies, wide-
spread CDE distributions in ternary plots are sug-
gested to be the key diagnostic character that
distinguishes in-situ, nondeformed MTDs from
confining non-MTD strata (Figure 17). In particular,
subhorizontal layered strata will be shown with
variable CD values, but very low D (Figure 17). This
observation is significant and has implications to
the distinction of different zones in MTDs, known
to comprise distinct internal fabrics and strata
thicknesses (Frey-Martinez et al., 2006). The CDE
method can therefore be used to recognize regions
of MTDs, at the same time allowing the quantifi-
cation of the seismic texture in such regions. This
postulate will be the basis of the following discus-
sion on the value of CDE values to distinguish
different zones in MTDs.

Contrasting (High-C) Strata as Reflecting
Lithological Contrasts and Distinct Degrees
of Disaggregation

In the blocky MTD from southeast Brazil, strata of
contrasting amplitudes are visible in distal and in-
termediate regions, where rafted blocks alternate
with adjacent debris flows (Figures 12, 13A, 14A).
This is a character common to translation zones of

formed blocks of strata whose downslope transla-
tion was limited, or suppressed at some point during

downslope movement (e.g., Mosher et al., 2004),
tend to present higher E, but variable D. Internal
features will preferentially follow the direction
of prevalent fabric or secondary directions of frac-
tures associated with major faults (e.g., Odling
et al., 1999). Such a change in the character of
remnant strata leads us to consider variable values
of C as reflecting distinct degrees of disaggrega-
tion in MTDs. In the case study from BES-100 in
southeast Brazil, disaggregated strata in between
blocks have low C, whereas distal strata compris-
ing multiple rafted blocks have high C. This char-
acter is interpreted to reflect different lithologies
in MTDs comprising relatively intact blocks and
confining debrites (Figure 17). Undisturbed high-
amplitude blocks, likely composed of lithified li-
thologies (higher Vp and shear strength), plot as
variable-D strata with low C and high E values
(Figures 13A, 14A, 17).

High Directionality (D) Reflecting Internal
Structural Fabric

Directionality (D) can vary according to any in-
herited or postdepositional fabric in MTDs. Fea-
tures with impact on the absolute values of D
include (1) compressional or extensional ridges in
translated strata, (2) vertical propagated faults from
underlying units, and (3) depressions caused by
differential compaction (Alves, 2010). At the basal
glide plane, erosional ridges, steps, and remnant
(but aligned) ridges of strata close to basal shear
planes of MTDs are important features of high D
(see Alves, 2013).
Toe regions show the largest variability in terms
of absolute values of D because of the existence of
inherited topography that will potentially con-
trol the degree of internal deformation of either
frontally emergent or frontally confined MTDs

and calcarenites in their interior (Caravelas Mem-
ber, França et al., 2007).

(Frey-Martinez et al, 2006). For instance, frontally
confined MTDs will present a toe region domi-
nated by compression of failed strata against de-
fined buttresses. Frontally emergent MTDs will
show unrestricted downslope translation of failed
strata until the slope angle will balance sediment
inertia and lead to the complete stop of the MTD
(Alves, 2013). Therefore, in toe regions of MTDs,
failed sediment will potentially show low C, D,
and E when reflecting a high degree of disaggre-
gation and very moderate amplitude contrasts in
strata. One significant control on C and E is the
nature of the source of material remobilized during
sea-floor failure; fine-grained material with large
plasticity will tend to present lower values of C and
E than coarser grained MTDs (Figure 17).
The relative value of D will depend on how
pervasive the structural fabric of an MTD is in re-
lation to C and E. Illustrating this fact, rafted strata
in the blocky MTD in BES-100 (southeast Brazil)
showing steep angles with the basal glide plane plot
as moderate to high D on the CDE ternary diagram
(Figure 17). A similar CDE distribution is observed
in MTD B from BM-ES-1, with D2 and D3 points
representing strata with large dip values.

Assessing Reservoir Potential and Seal
Competence with the Contrast, Directionality,
Energy Method

Figure 18 shows a series of ternary plots that sum-
marize the average CDE values calculated for the
case studies in this article. The same figure shows
values of D related to vertical structural dip. When
estimated visually from attribute maps, the inter-
preter can correlate the ternary plot data with
the nine classes of MTDs proposed, ranging from
C1-D1-E1 to C3-D3-E3. This procedure is flexible
enough to allow the boundaries between regions of
different risk in Figure 18B to be changed de-
pending on empirical data acquired on new bore-
hole sites.
The variable character of MTDs on seismic and
borehole data can therefore be simplified by the
use of ternary plots. In fact, barycentric systems
allow the interpreter to statistically plot any CDE
parameter and statistically correlate the calculated
values with borehole lithological and petrophysical
data (Figure 18A). The CDE method can be used
to assess the internal structure of any other types of
strata, with distinct textures, in any given direction.
Each measured point will have a CDE value that
totals 1.0 (or 100%) and representing a relative
proportion of C, D, and E to its internal charac-
ter. In essence, the interpreter should plot the
absolute values of CDE in a series of plots that
include the following:

High Energy (E) as a Function of
Acoustic Impedance

The absolute values of E will directly relate to the
acoustic impedance of strata. The value of E may
also depend on the presence of fluids (i.e., bright
spots or dim spots) in specific regions of MTDs,
thus making this parameter the most useful in
identifying the presence of reservoir potential in
MTDs. Regions with low D but variable C and E
represent strata with low or no remobilization.
These would represent, in a stratified reservoir,
the features with the larger reservoir potential.
This assumption is corroborated by the examples
in Figure 10, southeast Japan, in which turbidites
and hemipelagites in unit Ib are shown as high-E
continuous strata, and reveal a lower degree of dis-
aggregation in comparison to failed sediment in
MTD 6 (Figure 10). In southeast Brazil, large-scale
blocks also show energy values between E2 and
E3, likely in response to the presence of carbonates

1. Statistical plots extracted are compiled for the
three spatial directions, x–y–z. The more direct
way to assess the architecture of MTDs is to
undertake a statistical plot of CDE, with direc-
tionality being extracted from dip data of strata
within the MTD (Figure 18A). A value of D
approaching 1.0 will be given to vertical dip
angles (90o).
2. Petrophysical plots correlate the probability
distribution of sands, silt, and clays (or other
lithologies) with the CDE values calculated on
statistical plots.

in this work and their sealing risk. (A) Average CDE plot for the seven MTDs interpreted in this article. (B) Seal risk plot for the seven
MTDs, highlighting the central and uppermost part of CDE plots as representing the zones of higher seal risk. High-energy strata is
considered in this seal risk plot to relate to presence of lithified, cemented strata, excluding the presence of bright spots, bottom-
simulating reflections or any other evidence of subsurface fluid, common signs of compromised seal competency.

3. Risk plots are then calculated considering the
texture of the interpreted MTDs and their li-

The CDE data from MTDs considered in this
work plot toward the C corner of ternary plots

and show variable values of E and D (Figure 18B).
Low-energy–high-contrast and high-energy–low-
contrast strata are shown as the stratal types with
the lower risk in terms of fluid leakage, assuming
that high E values are not related to the presence
of fluids (i.e., bright spots). Moderate CDE values,

which are plotted toward the center of the ternary
diagrams, are the types of strata with the larger
sealing risk. Conversely, these will be the intervals
with the largest reservoir potential.
High-D strata (D2 and D3) are considered here
to also pose a high sealing risk if related to stratal
dip. Faulted MTDs will present variable seal risks
depending on the leakage factor of faults inter-
secting the MTD (e.g., Morris et al., 1996; Odling
et al., 2004). In the case studies documented in
this work, subhorizontal undisturbed strata plot
with a distinct character, allowing the separation
of marginal (undisturbed) strata and moderately
deformed and highly deformed strata as distinct
clusters on CDE ternary plots.

An important conclusion from this article is
that specific CDE distributions separate MTDs
from stratified intervals. When plotted on ternary
diagrams, CDE distributions can also be used to
identify distinct sediment sources from which MTDs
can derive. In particular, MTDs comprising coarse-
grained strata should differ from homogeneous
mudstones and shales in terms of their continuity,
internal architecture, and amplitude.
This work also shows that specific regions in
MTDs present specific C, D, and E values that can
be plotted against borehole petrophysical proper-
ties via ternary plots. The most common MTDs in
nature (chaotic to transparent) will plot as mod-
erate- to high-C and -D strata with relatively low
values of E. Strata with a marked vertical direc-
tionality (dilational faults or steeply dipping strata)
present high values of D. In essence, lower seal
competence is recorded in the strata with large D
or moderate C, D, and E values. High values of D
and E can be related with sandy, bedded horizons
with reservoir potential. They can also correlate
with the presence of fluids (bright spots), further
presenting the CDE method as a valid approach to
characterize MTDs in terms of their reservoir po-
tential and seal competence. By using this same
method for successive intervals, one can estimate
the degree of internal organization, continuity (or,
instead, chaos), and reflectivity of any type of
subsurface strata.
CONCLUSIONS

Three parameters are defined to classify the full
spectrum of MTDs strata in nature: contrast (C),
directionality (D), and energy (E) of high-amplitude
reflections within failed strata. These parameters
can be subdivided into nine classes that can be
correlated to any ground-truthed physical property
of MTDs. They are scale independent but survey
dependent because of the impact of distinct sur-
vey geometries and acquisition equipment on seis-
mic signals, a caveat resolved by statistically com-
paring absolute amplitude of reflections in MTDs
with background amplitude from confining strata,
or intervals of known lithology. As a result, the
CDE method is resolution independent and ap-
plicable to any marine geophysical data set al-
lowing attribute (and sound amplitude) extrac-
tion from MTDs. The data presented in this article
relate C, D, and E with the following properties:
